title: Building Your First Feature
description: Go from idea to working feature by planning with Claude, implementing step-by-step, and testing with real users.
learningObjectives: Break down a feature idea into implementable steps
Work with Claude to build a feature from scratch
Test your feature and gather initial feedback
Handle edge cases and improve based on testing

videos.title: Choosing Your First Feature
videos.description: How to pick a feature that's valuable, achievable, and teaches you the most.
scriptOutline: The MVP mindset: what's the smallest thing that adds value?
Feature prioritization for beginners: impact vs. complexity
Examples of good first features (contact form, dark mode, user profiles)
Examples of features to save for later (payments, real-time chat, AI integration)
How to scope: 'I want users to be able to [do one thing]'
talkingPoints: Your first feature should take 1-2 days max, not weeks
Pick something you can test yourself — no dependencies on others
Bonus points if it scratches your own itch
Don't pick 'authentication' for your first feature — too complex

videos.title: Planning with Claude: From Idea to Spec
videos.description: Shows how to use Claude to turn a vague idea into a detailed implementation plan.
scriptOutline: The planning prompt: 'I want to add [feature]. What do I need to consider?'
Claude as your product manager: asking about edge cases, UI, data
Reviewing the plan: files to create, files to modify, new dependencies
Breaking it into phases: v1 (basic), v2 (improved), v3 (polished)
Real example: planning the 'course progress tracker' for 02Ship
talkingPoints: Claude will think of edge cases you didn't — that's its job
Don't implement everything at once — build v1 first
A good plan answers: what files change, what's new, what could break
If the plan feels too complex, simplify the feature

videos.title: Implementation Walkthrough: Build It Step by Step
videos.description: Live coding session where we build a feature from start to finish using Claude.
scriptOutline: Step 1: Set up (install dependencies, create files)
Real example: building a 'bookmark this lesson' feature for 02Ship
talkingPoints: We're building this together — pause and follow along
Every step is small: add a file, test, commit
When something breaks, we debug together using Lesson 3 skills
The first version won't be perfect, and that's okay
Celebrate small wins: 'The button renders!' is progress

textSections.title: The Feature Planning Template
textSections.content:
Use this to plan any feature with Claude:

---

**Feature:** [One sentence description]

**User Story:** As a [user type], I want to [do something] so that [benefit].

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- [ ] When I [action], then [result]
- [ ] When I [action], then [result]
- [ ] [Edge case handling]

**Questions for Claude:**
- What files do I need to create or modify?
- What dependencies are required?
- What could go wrong (edge cases)?
- Can we build a simpler v1 first?

---

Example:

**Feature:** Bookmark lessons

**User Story:** As a learner, I want to bookmark lessons I want to return to later so that I can quickly find them.

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- [ ] When I click 'Bookmark', the lesson is saved
- [ ] When I visit /bookmarks, I see all my bookmarked lessons
- [ ] When I click 'Remove', the bookmark is deleted
- [ ] Bookmarks persist across sessions (localStorage)

**Questions for Claude:**
- What files do I need to create or modify?
- Should this use localStorage or a database?
- What happens if localStorage is full?
- Can we build a simpler v1 without a dedicated bookmarks page first?

textSections.title: Good First Features by Category
textSections.content:
**UI/UX Improvements:**
- Dark mode toggle
- Keyboard shortcuts
- Loading states / skeleton screens
- Improved mobile layout

**User Features:**
- Contact form
- Newsletter signup
- Comments section
- Search functionality

**Content Features:**
- Related posts/lessons
- Tags/categories
- Reading time estimate
- Share buttons

**Personalization:**
- Save preferences (language, theme)
- Recently viewed items
- Bookmarks / favorites
- Progress tracking

**Start with:** Something from UI/UX or Personalization — they're forgiving and immediately visible.

textSections.title: The Build-Test-Ship Cycle
textSections.content:
**1. Build the minimum version**
- Get it working, even if ugly
- Hard-code data if needed
- Skip error handling initially

**2. Test yourself**
- Click every button
- Try to break it
- Use it like a real user would

**3. Fix obvious bugs**
- Things that crash the app
- Confusing UX
- Visual glitches

**4. Ship it**
- Commit and deploy
- Tell someone to try it
- Gather feedback

**5. Iterate based on feedback**
- Add error handling
- Improve UX
- Handle edge cases

Repeat this cycle for every feature. Each cycle gets faster.

textSections.title: Testing Your Feature (No QA Team Required)
textSections.content:
**Manual testing checklist:**
- [ ] Does it work in Chrome? Safari? Mobile?
- [ ] What if I click the button twice quickly?
- [ ] What if I refresh the page mid-action?
- [ ] What if I'm offline? (for features using localStorage)
- [ ] What if the data is empty/missing?
- [ ] Can I navigate away and come back?

**Get feedback from:**
1. **Yourself** — Use it for real for 24 hours
2. **One friend** — Fresh eyes catch what you miss
3. **A stranger** (optional) — Loom video or Discord thread

**Red flags:**
- User asks 'how do I...?' → UX is unclear
- User does something you didn't expect → Edge case
- User can't complete the task → Core functionality broken

textSections.title: Key Definitions
textSections.content:
**Feature:** A discrete piece of functionality users interact with

**User Story:** A template describing who, what, and why for a feature

**Acceptance Criteria:** Specific conditions that must be met for the feature to be 'done'

**Edge Case:** An unusual scenario that might break your feature

**MVP (Minimum Viable Product):** The simplest version that provides value

**Ship:** To deploy/release your code so others can use it

commonMistakes.mistake: Picking a feature that's too big
commonMistakes.explanation: If it takes more than a weekend, break it into smaller features.
Test as you build — don't wait until the end.

commonMistakes.mistake: Trying to handle every edge case upfront
commonMistakes.explanation: Build the happy path first, add edge cases when you encounter them.
Commit every small working step — it's your undo button.
10 minutes of planning saves hours of re-work.

reflectionQuestions: What feature would make your project 10% more useful? Not perfect — just better.
Think about an app you use daily. What's one feature you wish it had? Could you build that?
What part of building features feels hardest: planning, coding, testing, or shipping?

exercises.title: Plan Your Feature
exercises.description: Choose a feature for your project and create a detailed plan with Claude.
exercises.output: A planning document using the template, including: feature description, user story, acceptance criteria, Claude's implementation plan
successCriteria: Chose a feature small enough to build in 1-2 days
Got Claude to provide: files to create/modify, dependencies, potential issues
Identified a simpler v1 if the full feature is complex

exercises.title: Build Your Feature (v1)
exercises.description: Implement the basic version of your planned feature using Claude.
exercises.output: A working feature deployed to your project, with git commits showing progress
successCriteria: Feature is implemented and visible in your project
Made at least 3 commits (setup, implementation, fixes)
Can demonstrate the feature to someone else

exercises.title: Test and Get Feedback
exercises.description: Have at least one other person try your feature and collect their feedback.
exercises.output: Feedback report containing: (1) What you asked them to do, (2) What they struggled with, (3) What worked well, (4) Your plan for v2 improvements
successCriteria: At least one person tested the feature
Documented their experience (even if it was 'worked fine')
Identified at least one improvement based on their feedback
Wrote a plan for one iteration to improve it

instructorNotes: This is the 'aha!' lesson — students realize they can build real features themselves.
For live sessions: Everyone builds the same simple feature (e.g., dark mode), then demos.
Common roadblock: Feature scope creep. Keep redirecting to 'what's the simplest version?'
Self-paced tip: Encourage students to screen-record their first feature build for their portfolio.
Time check: Exercise 2 is the meat — ensure 3-4 hour time block is realistic for your cohort.
Bonus: Create a showcase channel where students demo their first features to each other.
Meta moment: Point out that 02Ship's features were built exactly this way!
